title: Protocol for in vivo and in vitro study of lymphatic valve formation driven by shear stress signaling pathway
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
In vivo experiments
Tamoxifen preparation
Timing: 18 h
Protocol to prepare tamoxifen.
The following steps are to prepare tamoxifen in safflower oil.
In a 50 mL tube, add 0.5 mL of 100% EtOH.
Measure 200 mg tamoxifen powder on tare paper using a METTLER TOLEDO scale for accurate measurements.
Dissolve 200 mg tamoxifen powder in the 0.5 mL 100% EtOH.
Mix 9.5 mL safflower oil into the tube and tape it to a test tube rocker for ∼16 h mixing.
Seal the cap with Parafilm and cover the entire 50 mL tube with aluminum foil to protect tamoxifen from light exposure.
Pause point: mix for ∼16 h.
Next day, make sure the powder is all dissolved before aliquoting desired amount of tamoxifen into each tube.
Note: The amount of each aliquot depends on the volume of tamoxifen needed for every experiment. The leftover tamoxifen after every experiment is discarded to avoid freeze-thaw cycles.
Dissolved tamoxifen can be stored at −20°C for long term.
Critical: All tamoxifen material should be handled while wearing laboratory gloves and mask.
To identify plugged dams and calculate the date for the collection of embryos and postnatal pups
Timing: N/A
The following protocol is for the identification of a plugged dam.
For best results, mate one male mouse and 3 female mice in one cage.
Check plugs early in the morning every day.
The morning of seeing the plug is Embryonic day (E) 0.5.
Inject tamoxifen (TM) intraperitoneally for pregnant dams and subcutaneously for postnatal pups on required dates. Troubleshooting problem 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Calculate the date of analysis based on the plug observation.
Isolating tissues from embryos and pups for immunostaining
Timing: 2 days

This protocol breaks down the steps involved in isolating and processing mouse embryonic and postnatal tissues for whole-mount immunostaining. (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Pipeline of embryonic tissue collection and processing
For embryonic tissue collection, tamoxifen (TM) injected pregnant dams are euthanized by CO2 asphyxiation followed by cervical dislocation. Embryonic tissues are harvested in the following manner:
Place the euthanized pregnant dam face up on a flat surface.
Wet her abdomen with 70% EtOH and create a superficial incision in the skin using dissecting scissors without cutting through the peritoneal sac.
Cut across the skin longitudinally to reveal the peritoneal sac.
Create an incision in the peritoneal membrane and cut across longitudinally to expose the contents of the peritoneum.
Bare the uterine horn to unveil the number of embryos.
Note: At this point, label and keep ready 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes for embryonic tail collection for genotyping.
Excise the uterine horn from the body and place in ice cold 1× PBS.
Cut through the uterine membrane and uncover individual embryos.
Peel the amniotic sac enveloping individual embryos and separate the embryos from the placenta.
Note: Keep a 10 cm dish with ice cold 1× PBS ready.
Transfer the embryos to the 10 cm dish with ice cold 1X PBS.
Clip off about 2 mm of the tail and place the tails at the bottom of a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube for genotyping.
Critical: To prevent cross contamination of DNA during genotyping, 1) replace with fresh PBS if the solution is bloody; 2) keep embryos away from each other in the dish; and 3) clean the scissors used for tailing with 70% EtOH between each embryo.
Now the embryos are ready for tissue collection under the dissecting microscope.
Euthanize the embryos by decapitation.

To collect E16.5 and E18.5 axillary and back skin, pin the embryos onto a sylgard 184 pad and create an incision on the ventral lower abdominal skin using spring scissors and cut across the abdomen longitudinally to expose the peritoneal sac (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]).
Now separate the layer of skin from the peritoneal sac gently using Iris forceps and from mid abdomen to back left of the fetus, cutting connections whenever necessary.
Repeat on the right side.
You will now be able to pin out the skin, vascular side up, on a sylgard 184 pad.
To collect the mesentery, create an incision in the peritoneal membrane on the ventral lower abdomen using spring scissors and cut across longitudinally towards the neck exposing the organs of the peritoneal cavity (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Representative figure of mouse anatomy and dissection technique
(A) Animal in supine position with incision line (segmented white line).
(B) Animal with the peritoneal membrane exposed with incision line (segmented black line).
(C) The red circles highlight the external ears; the blue oblong highlights the diaphragm; and the white square highlights the mesentery.
Push the intestines and stomach towards the left using the blunt end of the iris forceps, snipping the connections between the mesentery and other organs wherever necessary.
Isolate the mesentery from the duodenum to the ileum from the body by excising the cecum and the stomach.
Pin out the mesentery on a sylgard 184 pad starting from the duodenum in a clockwise manner into a ring.
Note: Create multiple rings of the mesentery if necessary.
Note: Perform every step with caution as the embryonic skin and mesentery are extremely fragile and will rip. You will need intact lymphatic vessels stretching from the mesenteric lymph node to the gut for immunostaining.

Discard the embryos along with the dam in a red biohazard bag.
To fix embryonic tissues, use 1% paraformaldehyde (PFA).
Fix tissues in 1% PFA in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) for ∼16 h at 4°C. Troubleshooting problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Pause point: Overnight tissue fixation for ∼16 hours.
Next day, wash the tissues 3 times, 10 min each with PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) on an orbital shaker at 4°C.
For postnatal tissue collection of pre-weaning and weanling pups, TM injected pups are euthanized with an intraperitoneal ketamine overdose followed by cervical dislocation.
For mesentery collection from P8, P14, and P21 mice, place the pup ventrally on a flat surface and wet the ventral skin with 70% EtOH.
Create an incision on the lower abdominal skin and cut longitudinally across the skin using dissecting scissors to reveal the peritoneal sac (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2], white segmented line).
Create an incision in the peritoneal membrane and cut across longitudinally to expose the contents of the peritoneum (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2], black segmented line).
Use the iris forceps to move the intestines along with the stomach to the left of the body, cutting connections between the intestines and other organs wherever necessary.
Collect the mesentery from the duodenum to ileum by excising the stomach and the cecum and pin the mesentery as a ring (or multiple rings) on a sylgard 184 pad under the dissecting microscope. Troubleshoot problem 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Fix the mesenteries with 2% PFA for ∼16 h on an orbital shaker at 4°C. Troubleshooting problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
The next day, wash the tissue 3 times, 10 min each with PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) on an orbital shaker at 4°C.
Note: Make sure not to rip the lymphatic vessels as you will need structurally intact lymphatic vessels for immunostaining.

For ear collection from P21 pups, excise the ears from the head (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]):
Place the ear with the inner side facing up under the dissecting microscope on a flat surface.
Use a feather scalpel to slice the edge of the bottom corners of the ear to create a gap between the inner side and the outer side of the ear with the cartilage layer between these two sides.
Use precision tweezers to remove the inner side skin together with the cartilage layer from the outer side skin to reveal the underlying vascular dermis on the outer side skin.
Note: Take care to not break the cartilage layer or to leave any cartilage on the vascular dermis of the outer side skin. It will be difficult to image the ear lymphatics with a cartilage layer on top.
Pin down the outer side skin of the ear, vascular side up on a sylgard 184 pad along the edge.
Fix ear tissue in 2% PFA in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) for ∼16 h on an orbital shaker at 4°C. Troubleshooting problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Pause point: Overnight tissue fixation for ∼16 hours.
The next day, wash the tissue 3 times, 10 min each with PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) on an orbital shaker at 4°C.
To collect diaphragm from P21 pups, cut through the sternum to split the ribcage and reveal organs of the pleural cavity. The diaphragm will be at the end of the ribcage and above the liver (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]).
Hold the costal muscles with the iris forceps and snip at the muscle to release the diaphragm from the lower ribcage.
Snip all around the costal muscles to release the diaphragm from the ribcage and liver.
Finally separate the diaphragm from the vertebral column.

Pin the diaphragm on a sylgard 184 pad with the central tendon domain side up.
Note: Clean the central tendon domain off any connective tissue because the connective tissue can hamper imaging (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Representative GFP positive 25× image of a P21 diaphragm
Arrow points towards a GFPhigh valve. Scale bar is 250 μm.
Fix the diaphragm in 2% PFA in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) for ∼16 h on an orbital shaker at 4°C. Troubleshooting problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
Pause point: Overnight tissue fixation for ∼16 hours.
The next day, wash the tissue 3 times, 10 min each time on an orbital shaker at 4°C with PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%).
After fixation, all tissues can be stored at 4°C in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) within one week for further use (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Pipeline of postnatal tissue collection and processing
Critical: While collecting tissues for immunostaining, it is critical to not let the tissues dry out. Tissues are to be hydrated with fresh 1× PBS from time to time during collection. Fix the tissues in PFA at 4°C immediately after pinning them on the sylgard pads.
To process and genotype tail clips
Timing: ∼ 4 h
This protocol lists the steps in processing DNA from embryonic and postnatal mouse tail clips for genotyping.
About 2 mm tail is snipped from embryos or postnatal pups and placed in a 1.5 mL boil safe tube for processing.
Note: Set a heating block to 95°C and keep it ready.
For E16.5 tails: submerge the tail in 100 μL 50 mM NaOH.
For E18.5 and postnatal tails: submerge the tail in 200 μL 50 mM NaOH.
Place the tubes in 95°C heating block for 25 min.
Let the samples cool down.

Neutralize the samples with 1 M Tris-HCl pH 7.5.
For E16.5 tails: 20 μL 1 M Tris-HCl pH 7.5.
For E18.5 and postnatal tails: 40 μL 1 M Tris-HCl pH 7.5.
Vortex samples to mix reagents.
Centrifuge the samples at 13,000 g (10,730 rpm at 20°C–22°C) for 3 min.
Use immediately or store at −20°C.
Perform a standard PCR on a Biometra TRIO thermal cycler (analytik jena) to genotype the tail samples.
Cast an agarose gel and run the PCR product according to standard protocol to separate genomic bands according to size.
Image the gel using a BioRad ChemiDoc XRS+ system.
To perform immunostaining on tissues collected from embryos and postnatal mice
Timing: 2 days
Outlined here are the steps to perform immunostaining on embryonic and postnatal tissues collected from mice.
The tissues are pinned on sylgard 184 pads on 35 mm petri dishes. All steps are performed at 4°C on an orbital shaker, unless stated otherwise.
Day 1:
Permeabilize the fixed tissues using 4 mL of PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) + 0.3% Triton (PBST – permeabilization buffer) per dish for at least 1 h.
Optional: The samples can be in PBST over an hour.
Block the samples in 3% donkey serum in 2 mL PBST per dish for at least 2 h.
Optional: The blocking step can go over 2 hours.
Note: Prepare your primary antibodies in 1.5 mL PBST per dish. Triple staining can be performed on the samples. But make sure not to stain two antibodies raised in the same species.
Incubate the samples with the prepared primary antibodies and mix for ∼16 h at 4°C.
Pause point: Incubation of samples in primary antibodies for ∼16 h.
Day 2:
Wash the samples with 4 mL PBST, 5 times, and 10 min each time.

Note: Prepare secondary antibodies in 1.5 mL PBST in a dark bodied tube.
Incubate the samples in secondary antibodies for 1.5 h on an orbital shaker at 20°C–22°C in a black-out box to prevent light exposure.
Wash the samples with 4 mL PBST, 5 times, 10 min each.
Optional: Conjugated antibodies can be incubated together with the secondary antibodies.
Note: Prepare DAPI in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%) in a dark bodied tube (2 mL per dish).
Incubate samples in DAPI (1 μg/mL) for 5 min.
Wash samples with 4 mL PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%), once for 5 min.
Mount the tissues on the slides with mounting media.
Carefully place a cover slip on top of the tissues without any bubbles.
Critical: If you plan to mount on another day, make sure to store the tissues in mounting media at 4°C. Do not store the samples in PBS (1×) + NaN3 (0.05%).
Image the immunostained slides using:
A Zeiss V16 fluorescence microscope. Troubleshooting problem 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
A Leica SP8 confocal fluorescence microscope.
To image tissues for lymphatic valve counting, measuring lymphatic vessel length, and diameter.
Timing: ∼1 h per animal
This protocol lists the steps involved in ex vivo imaging of mouse tissues for lymphatic valve counting.
A GFP reporter mouse line was bred with the experimental mice for visualization of lymphatic vessels and valves.
A Zeiss V16 fluorescence microscope was used to capture images of GFP positive mesenteric lymphatic vessels.
To count lymphatic valves in embryonic mesentery, image the whole ring of pinned out mesenteric lymphatic vessels under a Zeiss V16 fluorescence microscope with the Zen Pro software (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] and 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6]).

(B) Higher magnification image of a GFP positive E18.5 mesentery showing a single mesenteric lymphatic vessel.
White arrows indicate GFPhigh valves. Scale bars are 500 μm.
To count lymphatic valves in postnatal mesentery, images of each mesenteric collecting lymphatic vessel and its branches were captured under a Zeiss V16 microscope (Figures 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5] and 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).

(A) A 12.5× image of P14 collecting lymphatic vessels.
(B) A 32× image of the white box area from image A.
Scale bars are 500 μm. White arrows indicate GFPhigh valves.
Overdose and euthanize the TM injected postnatal pup with ketamine followed by cervical dislocation.
Place the euthanized pup abdomen side up on a flat surface.
Wet the abdominal skin using 70% EtOH and create an incision on the skin.
Cut longitudinally towards the neck to reveal the peritoneal sac.
Create an incision on the peritoneal membrane and cut longitudinally towards the neck to expose the organs of the peritoneum and pleural cavity.
Make lateral cuts on the skin all the way to the back to expose the ribcage and the organs inferior to it (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Place the animal on its left side, so the right side is facing up, on a flat surface.
Place a sylgard 184 semicircular pad next to the belly of the animal to serve as a stage to pin the mesentery for easy imaging (Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5]).
Note: Use 1× PBS to hydrate the mesentery at all times of dissection and imaging. It is critical to not let the organ dry.

To identify the first lymphatic vessel at the duodenum arising from the mesenteric lymph node, use the iris forceps and carefully expose the part of the mesentery inferior to the pancreas.
Place pins wherever necessary to expose the full length of the vessel and capture an image of the GFP positive mesentery under the V16 microscope using the Zen Pro software.
Acquire images in the GFP channel under low and high magnification of each collecting lymphatic vessel by exposing the mesenteric lymphatic vessels of the duodenum, jejunum, and ileum.
The image frame must display the lymphatic vessel arising from the lymph node all the way to the gut (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
Note: At this point it is useful to capture higher magnification images of the lymphatic vessels and valves from representative branches (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]).
To count lymphatic valves in P21 ears, excise and pin the ear, inner vascular side up, on a sylgard 184 pad as explained in step 2b of "Isolating tissues from embryos and pups for immunostaining" (Figure 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig8]).

In vitro experiments
Timing: ∼2 h

This section highlights the steps involved in the culturing and passaging of human dermal lymphatic endothelial cells (hdLECs) before performing experiments.
Culturing human dermal lymphatic endothelial cells
The protocol below enlists the steps in thawing, culturing, and passaging previously frozen hdLECs.
All steps are performed in a Class II laminar flow hood unless mentioned otherwise. While thawing cells:
Coat required number of wells of 6-well plates with fibronectin – 2 μg/cm2 fibronectin in 1 mL DPBS per well.
Note: The number of wells is calculated based on seeding 1 × 105 cells per well.
Note: Fibronectin coating supports hdLECs to have flow responses.
Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 30 min in a humidified cell culture incubator.
Note: hdLECs are stored in liquid N2 for long-term storage.
Prepare complete endothelial cell growth medium MV 2 by adding supplement mix to the endothelial cell basal medium MV2 according to manufacturer’s instructions.
Note: Keep ready a 15 mL tube with 9 mL of complete Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 in a Class II laminar flow hood.
Thaw frozen hdLECs cryovial in a 37°C water bath until very little frozen solution remains.
Quickly and generously spray the vial with 70% EtOH, wipe the tube.
Transfer the contents into the 15 mL tube containing Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2.
Centrifuge the cellular suspension for 5 min at 400 g at 20°C–22°C.
Quickly remove the supernatant media and resuspend the pellet with 1 mL of Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2.
Pipette up and down to create a homogenous cell resuspension.
Add the remaining Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 to make the full volume cell resuspension (1.5 mL media in each well).

Remove the fibronectin using a vacuum aspiration system (e.g., VACTRAP™) inside of the hood and add 1.5 mL of cell resuspension to each well.
Rock the plate back and forth and side to side to ensure equal distribution of cells.
Incubate the cells at 37°C, 5% CO2 in a cell culture incubator.
While passaging cultured cells:
Note: Coat required wells of 6-well plates with 2 μg/cm2 fibronectin per well and incubate in a humidified cell culture incubator for 30 min.
Note: Seed 1 × 105 cells per well of a 6-well plate.
Remove Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 from the cultured wells and wash the cells with 1 mL of DPBS.
Incubate the wells with 1 mL of 0.5% Trypsin-EDTA for 3 min at 37°C, 5% CO2 in a cell culture incubator.
Note: After 3 min, check if cells are floating in the well. If not, incubate for another minute and check again. Repeat if necessary.
Once cells have detached from the plate, add 1 mL of Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 to stop trypsinization.
Collect the cell suspension in a 15 mL tube and centrifuge for 5 min at 400 g at 20°C–22°C to obtain a pellet and supernatant.
Remove the supernatant and resuspend the cell pellet with 1 mL of Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2.
Pipette up and down to create a homogenous cell resuspension.
For counting cell number using LUNA-II automated cell counter:
Mix 10 μL of cell resuspension with 10 μL of trypan blue dye.
Load 10 μL of cell-dye mixture onto the commercial slides and read the concentration and the viability of the cells on the cell counter.

The viability of the cells should be > 90% and around 1.2 × 106 per mL can be obtained from 3 confluent wells of a 6-well plate.
Add the required amount of Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 to make up required volume.
Pipette 1.5 mL of cell resuspension into each fibronectin coated well of 6-well plates and incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 in a cell culture incubator.
To prepare for immunostaining on cultured cells:
Using forceps, place a 70% EtOH soaked 22 × 22 (mm2) coverslip standing up on each well of a 6-well plate.
Air-dry the coverslip in the Class II laminar flow hood for 30 mins (Figure 10[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig10]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig10.jpg
Figure 10. Preparing coverslips for in vitro immunostaining
Drop the coverslip into the plate making sure it is lying flat.
Coat the coverslip containing wells with fibronectin (2 μg/cm2) and incubate in the humidified cell culture incubator for 30 min.
Remove the fibronectin from the wells using the vacuum aspiration system (e.g., VACTRAP™).
Passage hdLECs onto the coverslip containing wells.
Critical: Generally, hdLECs require media change every 48 hours.
To expose cultured human dermal lymphatic endothelial cells to oscillatory flow
Timing: ∼4 days
Lymph flow is oscillatory; hence, lymphatic vessels experience oscillatory shear stress (OSS), which is crucial for the expression of valve genes.4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] To perform in vitro experiments on hdLECs exposed to flow conditions, an optimized rocker technique that simulates the OSS experienced by lymphatic endothelial cells (LECs) on hdLECs in 6-well plates was applied to study flow responses. The following are detailed steps for an experiment that requires hdLEC exposure to flow.
Seed 1 × 105 cells per well to start the culture.
Remove Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 media from 90%–95% confluent cells.

Perform polybrene (infection agent, 5 μg/mL) mediated lentiviral shscramble/shRNA (MOI = 120) infection for 48 h (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]). Troubleshoot problem 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig11.jpg
Figure 11. Pipeline of in vitro experiments performed on hdLECs
Incubate the plates in a cell culture incubator at 37°C, 5% CO2.
After designated treatment time, replace with fresh complete endothelial cell growth medium and dispose the media with lentiviruses in freshly made 10% bleach.
Add 1.5 mL Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 media for static conditions and 1 mL Endothelial Cell Growth Medium MV 2 media for flow conditions.
Note: Prepare the rocker in the incubator. Set the rocker to 18 rpm at a 48° which is optimized rocking for lymphatic in vitro experiments.5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]
Place the plate on the rocker in a humidified cell culture incubator for required time.
To quantify the expression levels of valve genes using quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR), western blot, and/or immunostaining, cells are exposed to flow conditions for 48 h (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).
To quantify phosphorylated proteins using western blot, and/or immunostaining, cells are exposed to flow conditions for a shorter period of time (10/30/60 min) (Figure 11[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig11]).
Note: Some protocols might require 10/30/60 min of flow exposure. hdLECs once taken off flow must be quickly processed for respective experiments.
Note: Infection of lentiviral shRNA is not required for flow treatment. hdLECs without viral infection or with different types of infection or transfection (e.g., overexpression or plasmid transfection) are suitable for flow treatment as long as cells are fully confluent before flow starts.
Quantitative real time polymerase chain reaction
Timing: at most 2 days
This protocol describes the steps to perform RNA extraction, reverse transcription, and cDNA synthesis for a qRT-PCR using cultured hdLECs.
To collect RNA from cultured hdLECs:

Follow manufacturer’s protocol to extract total RNA from hdLECs using Qiagen RNeasy® Plus Mini Kit.
Critical: Use RNase free tubes for RNA extraction.
Note: Use 350 μL buffer RLT plus 3.5 μL β-mercaptoethanol (BME) to collect RNA from two wells of a 6-well plate with fully confluent cells.
After adding 15–25 μL RNase free water to the spin column membrane, wait 1 min to allow the water to soak into the membrane before centrifuging.
After extracting RNA, pipette 2 μL RNase free water control onto two microspots of the Take3 microvolume plate and pipette 2 μL of samples onto the microspot.
Read the plate using an absorbance reader for RNA concentration.
Use a nucleic acid quantification protocol without lid to read the plate.
The A260/A280 ratio should be between 1.9 and 2.2 for the purest RNA extraction. Troubleshooting problem 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Store the RNA samples at −80°C for long-term storage.
For reverse transcription and cDNA synthesis:
Thaw RNA samples on ice.
Perform reverse transcription using 1,000 ng (1 μg) RNA sample (Figure 12[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig12]).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2587-Fig12.jpg
Figure 12. Preparing RNA samples for reverse transcription
Perform cDNA synthesis following the Advantage RT-for-PCR kit following manufacturer’s instructions.[href=https://www.takarabio.com/documents/User%20Manual/PT1107/PT1107-1.pdf]
Post the PCR, dilute cDNA with Ultrapure distilled water (PCR water) at 1:16 for qRT-PCR.
RNA and cDNA can be stored at −80°C for long term use.
Perform a qRT-PCR to quantify gene expression.
Note: For every gene to be detected, each cDNA sample requires 3 wells as triplicates. The TaqMan probes are stored at −20°C, so thaw them on ice well in advance.
Prepare the PCR master mix by pipetting the TaqMan fast mix and the Taqman probe into an Eppendorf tube.

Note: Multiply the number of wells based on the number of genes to be detected. For example, if the expression levels of 5 genes are to be analyzed, the total number of wells for preparing the master mix will be 3 × 5 = 15 wells. To compensate for the pipetting error, prepare the master mix for an extra well. So, it will be 16 wells (Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1]).

Pipette 5.5 μL PCR master mix for a probe into each well of a 384 well plate.
Add the 4.5 μL cDNA template after.
Note: Use GAPDH as control.
Seal the qPCR plate with a transparent optical adhesive cover.
Run a qRT-PCR on a QuantStudio 6 real-time PCR system.
Run program for a fast standard curve.
The program should take about 32 min.
Note: Choose the program for qRT-PCR according to the type of TaqMan PCR master mix.
Immunostaining of hdLECs
Timing: 2 days
The following protocol lists out the steps involved in in vitro staining of cultured hdLECs.
Day 1:
Culture the cells on the glass coverslips.
When the cells are ready, remove the media and wash the cells with PBS once.
Fix them with 4% PFA for 12 min at 20°C–22°C.
Wash three times with PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%), 5 min each time.
Note: You can store the cells in 4 degrees at this step. But make sure that the cells don’t dry, and bacteria contamination does not occur during storage.
Permeabilize the cells with 0.1% triton+PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%) for 20 min at 20°C–22°C.
Block the cells with 3% donkey serum in PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%) (blocking buffer) for 30 min to 1 h at 20°C–22°C.
Dilute the antibodies in the blocking buffer according to the concentration.
Add primary antibodies.
Note: For square coverslips, 200 μL blocking buffer is sufficient.

Incubate in the wet box for ∼16 h at 4°C.
Day 2:
Wash three times with PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%), 5 min each time.
Dilute the secondary antibodies in the PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%) according to the concentration.
Add secondary antibodies.
Incubate in the wet box for 1 h at 20°C–22°C.
Wash three times with PBS (1X)+NaN3 (0.05%), 5 min each time.
Mount with mounting media and image.
